#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Chapter XXXII .
#Text=THE FEAST OF BELSHAZZAR : A SEER TO TRANSLATE
#Text=Such feelings as were generated in Carrie by this walk put her in an exceedingly receptive mood for the pathos which followed in the play .
#Text=The actor whom they had gone to see had achieved his popularity by presenting a mellow type of comedy , in which sufficient sorrow was introduced to lend contrast and relief to humour .
#Text=For Carrie , as we well know , the stage had a great attraction .
#Text=She had never forgotten her one histrionic achievement in Chicago .
#Text=It dwelt in her mind and occupied her consciousness during many long afternoons in which her rocking-chair and her latest novel contributed the only pleasures of her state .
#Text=Never could she witness a play without having her own ability vividly brought to consciousness .
#Text=Some scenes made her long to be a part of them — to give expression to the feelings which she , in the place of the character represented , would feel .
#Text=Almost invariably she would carry the vivid imaginations away with her and brood over them the next day alone .
#Text=She lived as much in these things as in the realities which made up her daily life .
#Text=It was not often that she came to the play stirred to her heart ’s core by actualities .
#Text=To-day a low song of longing had been set singing in her heart by the finery , the merriment , the beauty she had seen .
#Text=Oh , these women who had passed her by , hundreds and hundreds strong , who were they ?
#Text=Whence came the rich , elegant dresses , the astonishingly coloured buttons , the knick-knacks of silver and gold ?
#Text=Where were these lovely creatures housed ?
#Text=Amid what elegancies of carved furniture , decorated walls , elaborate tapestries did they move ?
#Text=Where were their rich apartments , loaded with all that money could provide ?
#Text=In what stables champed these sleek , nervous horses and rested the gorgeous carriages ?
#Text=Where lounged the richly groomed footmen ?
#Text=Oh , the mansions , the lights , the perfume , the loaded boudoirs and tables !
#Text=New York must be filled with such bowers , or the beautiful , insolent , supercilious creatures could not be .
#Text=Some hothouses held them .
#Text=It ached her to know that she was not one of them — that , alas , she had dreamed a dream and it had not come true .
#Text=She wondered at her own solitude these two years past — her indifference to the fact that she had never achieved what she had expected .
#Text=The play was one of those drawing-room concoctions in which charmingly overdressed ladies and gentlemen suffer the pangs of love and jealousy amid gilded surroundings .
#Text=Such bon-mots are ever enticing to those who have all their days longed for such material surroundings and have never had them gratified .
#Text=They have the charm of showing suffering under ideal conditions .
#Text=Who would not grieve upon a gilded chair ?
#Text=Who would not suffer amid perfumed tapestries , cushioned furniture , and liveried servants ?
#Text=Grief under such circumstances becomes an enticing thing .
#Text=Carrie longed to be of it .
#Text=She wanted to take her sufferings , whatever they were , in such a world , or failing that , at least to simulate them under such charming conditions upon the stage .
#Text=So affected was her mind by what she had seen , that the play now seemed an extraordinarily beautiful thing .
#Text=She was soon lost in the world it represented , and wished that she might never return .
#Text=Between the acts she studied the galaxy of matinée attendants in front rows and boxes , and conceived a new idea of the possibilities of New York .
#Text=She was sure she had not seen it all — that the city was one whirl of pleasure and delight .
#Text=Going out , the same Broadway taught her a sharper lesson .
#Text=The scene she had witnessed coming down was now augmented and at its height .
#Text=Such a crush of finery and folly she had never seen .
#Text=It clinched her convictions concerning her state .
#Text=She had not lived , could not lay claim to having lived , until something of this had come into her own life .
#Text=Women were spending money like water ; she could see that in every elegant shop she passed .
#Text=Flowers , candy , jewelry , seemed the principal things in which the elegant dames were interested .
#Text=And she — she had scarcely enough pin money to indulge in such outings as this a few times a month .
#Text=That night the pretty little flat seemed a commonplace thing .
#Text=It was not what the rest of the world was enjoying .
#Text=She saw the servant working at dinner with an indifferent eye .
#Text=In her mind were running scenes of the play .
#Text=Particularly she remembered one beautiful actress — the sweetheart who had been wooed and won .
#Text=The grace of this woman had won Carrie ’s heart .
#Text=Her dresses had been all that art could suggest , her sufferings had been so real .
#Text=The anguish which she had portrayed Carrie could feel .
#Text=It was done as she was sure she could do it .
#Text=There were places in which she could even do better .
#Text=Hence she repeated the lines to herself .
#Text=Oh , if she could only have such a part , how broad would be her life !
#Text=She , too , could act appealingly .
#Text=When Hurstwood came , Carrie was moody .
#Text=She was sitting , rocking and thinking , and did not care to have her enticing imaginations broken in upon ; so she said little or nothing .
#Text=“ What ’s the matter , Carrie ? ” said Hurstwood after a time , noticing her quiet , almost moody state .
